Questions: Are sour foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?
Answers: In a clean spot, having established a firm seat of his own, neither too high nor too low, made of cloth, skin, and kusha grass layered one over the other.

Questions: Are sour foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?
Answers: In a clean spot, having established a firm seat of his own, neither too high nor too low, made of cloth, skin, and kusha grass layered one over the other.

Questions: Are sour foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?
Answers: There, having made the mind one-pointed, with the actions of the mind and senses controlled, let him, seated on the seat, practice Yoga for the purification of the self.

Questions: Are sour foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?
Answers: Let him firmly hold his body, head, and neck erect and still, gazing at the tip of his nose without looking around.

Questions: Which foods are considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Serene-minded, fearless, firm in the vow of a Brahmachari, having controlled their mind, thinking of Me and balanced in mind, let them sit, having Me as their supreme goal.

Questions: Which foods are considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Thus, always keeping the mind balanced, the yogi, with the mind controlled, attains the peace abiding in Me, culminating in liberation.

Questions: Which foods are considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Verily, Yoga is not possible for him who eats too much, nor for him who does not eat at all, nor for him who sleeps too much, nor for him who is always awake, O Arjuna.

Questions: Which foods are considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Verily, Yoga is not possible for him who eats too much, nor for him who does not eat at all, nor for him who sleeps too much, nor for him who is always awake, O Arjuna.

Questions: Which foods are considered to generate lethargy?
Answers: Verily, Yoga is not possible for him who eats too much, nor for him who does not eat at all, nor for him who sleeps too much, nor for him who is always awake, O Arjuna.

Questions: Which foods are considered to generate lethargy?
Answers: Yoga becomes the destroyer of pain for him who is moderate in eating and recreation (such as walking, etc.), who exercises moderation in action, and who is moderate in sleep and wakefulness.

Questions: Which foods are considered to generate lethargy?
Answers: Yoga becomes the destroyer of pain for him who is moderate in eating and recreation (such as walking, etc.), who exercises moderation in action, and who is moderate in sleep and wakefulness.

Questions: Which foods are considered to generate lethargy?
Answers: When the perfectly controlled mind rests in the Self alone, free from longing for any of the objects of desire, then it is said, 'He is united'.

Questions: Are stale foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?
Answers: As a lamp placed in a windless spot does not flicker, so is the Yogi of a controlled mind, who practices Yoga in the Self, compared.

Questions: Are stale foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?
Answers: As a lamp placed in a windless spot does not flicker, so is the Yogi of a controlled mind, who practices Yoga in the Self, compared.

Questions: Are stale foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?
Answers: As a lamp placed in a windless spot does not flicker, so is the Yogi of a controlled mind, who practices Yoga in the Self, compared.

Questions: Are stale foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?
Answers: When the mind, restrained by the practice of yoga, attains quietude, and when one sees the Self by the Self, they are satisfied in their own Self.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered sattvic?
Answers: When he (the Yogi) feels that infinite bliss which can be grasped by the pure intellect and which transcends the senses, and is established therein, never moving away from the reality.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered sattvic?
Answers: Having obtained it, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; established in it, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered sattvic?
Answers: Having obtained it, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; established in it, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered sattvic?
Answers: Having obtained it, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; established in it, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered pure?
Answers: Let this be known by the name of Yoga, the severance from union with pain. This Yoga should be practiced with determination and with an undespairing mind.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered pure?
Answers: Let this be known by the name of Yoga, the severance from union with pain. This Yoga should be practiced with determination and with an undespairing mind.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered pure?
Answers: Abandoning unreservedly all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of senses by the mind from all sides.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered pure?
Answers: Little by little, let him attain steadiness of the intellect by holding it firmly; having made the mind establish itself in the Self, let him not think of anything else.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered rajasic?
Answers: From whatever cause the restless and unsteady mind wanders away, let him restrain it from that and bring it under the control of the Self alone.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered rajasic?
Answers: Supreme Bliss indeed comes to this Yogi whose mind is made peaceful, whose passion is quelled, who has become Brahman, and who is free from sin.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered rajasic?
Answers: The yogi, always engaging the mind thus (in the practice of yoga), is freed from sins and easily enjoys the infinite bliss of contact with Brahman (the Eternal).

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered rajasic?
Answers: With the mind harmonized by Yoga, he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?
Answers: He who sees Me everywhere and sees everything in Me, never becomes separated from Me, nor do I from him.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?
Answers: He who, being established in unity, worships Me, who dwells in all beings, that yogi abides in Me, whatever their mode of living may be.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?
Answers: He who, through the likeness of the Self, O Arjuna, sees reality everywhere, be it pleasure or pain, is regarded as the highest Yogi.

Questions: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, I do not see how this Yoga of equanimity, which you have taught me, can be maintained steadily, due to the restlessness of the mind."

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: The mind is indeed restless, turbulent, strong, and unyielding, O Krishna; I consider it as difficult to control as controlling the wind.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the mind is difficult to control and restless; but with practice and dispassion, it can be restrained."

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: I think Yoga is hard to be attained by one with an uncontrolled self, but the self-controlled and striving one can attain it by the appropriate means.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the body?
Answers: Arjuna said, "He who is unable to control himself, even though he has faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he meet, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, O Krishna?"

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: Fallen from both, does he not perish like a rent cloud, supportless, O mighty-armed one, deluded on the path of Brahman?

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: O Krishna, please completely dispel this doubt of mine, for it is not possible for anyone but You to do so.

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, neither in this world nor in the next will there be destruction for him; none, indeed, who does good, O my son, ever comes to grief."

Questions: What is considered to be bodily austerity?
Answers: Having attained to the worlds of the righteous and having dwelt there for everlasting years, he who fell from Yoga is born in a house of the pure and wealthy.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?
Answers: Or he is born in a family of even the wisest of yogis; verily, such a birth is very difficult to obtain in this world.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?
Answers: Then he comes into contact with the knowledge acquired in his former body and strives even more for perfection, O Arjuna.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?
Answers: By that same former practice, he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmanic word.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of speech?
Answers: But the Yogi who strives assiduously, purified of sins and perfected gradually over many births, reaches the highest goal.

Questions: Is recitation of scriptures a good idea?
Answers: The yogi is thought to be superior to the ascetics, even superior to those who have knowledge obtained through the study of scriptures; he is also superior to men of action; therefore, be thou a yogi, O Arjuna.

Questions: Is recitation of scriptures a good idea?
Answers: And among all the Yogis, he who, full of faith and with his inner self merged in Me, worships Me is deemed by Me to be the most devoted.

Questions: Is recitation of scriptures a good idea?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, hear how you shall, without doubt, know Me fully, with your mind intent on Me, practicing Yoga and taking refuge in Me."

Questions: Is recitation of scriptures a good idea?
Answers: I will declare to you in full this knowledge combined with realization, after knowing which nothing else remains to be known here.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the mind?
Answers: Among thousands of men, one may perchance strive for perfection; even among those successful strivers, only one may perchance know Me in essence.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the mind?
Answers: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and egoism—thus is My Nature divided eightfold.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the mind?
Answers: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and egoism—thus is My Nature divided eightfold.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of the mind?
Answers: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and egoism—thus is My Nature divided eightfold.

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and egoism—thus is My Nature divided eightfold.

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: O mighty-armed Arjuna, this is the inferior Prakriti; know it as distinct from My higher Prakriti, the very life-element, by which this world is upheld.

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: Know that these two are the womb of all beings; thus, I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe.

Questions: What is considered to be sattvic austerity?
Answers: There is nothing higher than Me, O Arjuna. All this is strung on Me, like clusters of gems on a string.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of sattva?
Answers: I am the flavor in water, O Arjuna; I am the light in the moon and the sun; I am the syllable Om in all the Vedas, sound in the ether and virility in men.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of sattva?
Answers: I am the flavor in water, O Arjuna; I am the light in the moon and the sun; I am the syllable Om in all the Vedas, sound in the ether and virility in men.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of sattva?
Answers: I am the sweet fragrance in the earth and the brilliance in the fire, the life in all beings, and I am the austerity of ascetics.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of sattva?
Answers: Know Me, O Arjuna, as the eternal seed of all beings; I am the intelligence of the intelligent, and the splendour of the splendid objects.

Questions: What is considered to be pure austerity?
Answers: Of the strong, I am the strength devoid of desire and attachment, and in all beings, I am the desire in accordance with Dharma, O Arjuna.

Questions: What is considered to be pure austerity?
Answers: Whatever beings (and objects) that are pure, active, and inert, know that they proceed from Me. They are in Me, yet I am not in them.

Questions: What is considered to be pure austerity?
Answers: Deluded by these Natures, composed of the three qualities of Nature, all this world does not know Me as distinct from them and immutable.

Questions: What is considered to be pure austerity?
Answers: Verily, this divine illusion of Mine, composed of the three qualities, is difficult to cross over; those who take refuge in Me alone, can cross over this illusion.

Questions: What is considered to be rajasic austerity?
Answers: The evil-doers and the deluded, who are the lowest of men, do not seek Me; those whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.

Questions: What is considered to be rajasic austerity?
Answers: Four kinds of virtuous men worship Me, O Arjuna, and they are the distressed, the seekers of knowledge, the seekers of wealth, and the wise, O Lord of the Bharatas.

Questions: What is considered to be rajasic austerity?
Answers: Of them, the wise who are ever steadfast and devoted to the One, excel; for I am exceedingly dear to the wise, and they are dear to Me.

Questions: What is considered to be rajasic austerity?
Answers: Of them, the wise who are ever steadfast and devoted to the One, excel; for I am exceedingly dear to the wise, and they are dear to Me.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Indeed, all these are noble; however, I consider the wise man as My very Self; for, he is steadfast in mind and established in Me alone as the supreme goal.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: At the end of many births, the wise man comes to Me, realizing that all this is Vaasudeva (the innermost Self); such a great soul (Mahatma) is very hard to find.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Those whose wisdom has been taken away by this or that desire, go to other gods, following this or that rite, led by their own nature.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of rajas?
Answers: Whatever form any devotee desires to worship with faith, I make that same faith of his firm and unflinching.

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?
Answers: Whatever form any devotee desires to worship with faith, I make that same faith of his firm and unflinching.

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?
Answers: Endowed with that faith, he engages in the worship of that form and obtains his desired outcome, which is ordained by Me alone.

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?
Answers: Verily, the reward (fruit) that accrues to those men of small intelligence is finite. The worshippers of the gods go to them, whereas My devotees come to Me.

Questions: What is considered to be tamasic austerity?
Answers: The foolish think of Me, the Unmanifest, as having manifestation, not knowing My higher, immutable, and most excellent nature.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: I am not manifest to all, veiled as I am by the Yoga-Maya. This deluded world does not know Me, who am unborn and imperishable.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: I know, O Arjuna, the beings of the past, the present, and the future; however, no one knows Me.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: O Bharata, all beings are subject to delusion at birth due to the delusion of the pairs of opposites arising from desire and aversion, O Parantapa.

Questions: What is considered to be austerity of tamas?
Answers: But those men of virtuous deeds, whose sins have come to an end and who are freed from the delusion of the pairs of opposites, worship Me steadfastly, with their vows.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, realize in full that Brahman, the whole knowledge of the Self, and all action.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Those who know Me with the Adhibhuta (pertaining to the elements), Adhidaiva (pertaining to the gods), and the Adhiyajna (pertaining to the sacrifice) know Me even at the time of death, remaining steadfast in mind.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Arjuna said, "What is Brahman? What is Adhyatma? What is action, O best among men? What is Adhibhuta declared to be? And, what is Adhidaiva said to be?"

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Who and how is Adhiyajna here in this body, O destroyer of Madhu? And how, at the time of death, are You to be known by the self-controlled?

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be pure?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Brahman is the Imperishable, the Supreme; its essential nature is called Self-knowledge; the offering (to the gods) that causes the existence and manifestation of beings and sustains them is called action."

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be pure?
Answers: Adhibhuta—knowledge of the elements—pertains to My perishable nature, and the Purusha, or the Soul, is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be pure?
Answers: Adhibhuta—knowledge of the elements—pertains to My perishable nature, and the Purusha, or the Soul, is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be pure?
Answers: Adhibhuta—knowledge of the elements—pertains to My perishable nature, and the Purusha, or the Soul, is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be rajasic?
Answers: And whoever, leaving their body, goes forth remembering Me alone at the time of death, they will attain My Being; there is no doubt about this.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Whoever at the end leaves the body, thinking of any being, to that being only does he go, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), due to his constant thought of that being.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Therefore, at all times, remember Me only and fight. With your mind and intellect fixed on Me, you will undoubtedly come to Me alone.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be rajasic?
Answers: With the mind not moving towards any other thing, made steadfast through the practice of habitual meditation, and constantly meditating, one goes to the Supreme Person, the Resplendent, O Arjuna.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Whosoever meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler of the whole world, minuter than an atom, the supporter of all, of inconceivable form, effulgent like the sun and beyond the darkness of ignorance.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be tamasic?
Answers: At the time of death, with an unwavering mind, endowed with devotion, by the power of Yoga, fixing the whole life-breath in the middle of the two eyebrows, he reaches that resplendent Supreme Person.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be tamasic?
Answers: That which is declared to be Imperishable by those who know the Vedas, that which the self-controlled (ascetics or Sannyasins) and passion-free enter, that goal, desiring which celibacy is practised, I will declare to thee in brief.

Questions: What kind of gifts are considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart, and fixed the life-breath in the head, engage in the practice of concentration.

Questions: what is the meaning and significance of om tat sat?
Answers: Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart, and fixed the life-breath in the head, engage in the practice of concentration.

Questions: what is the meaning and significance of om tat sat?
Answers: Uttering the one-syllabled Om, the Brahman, and remembering Me, he who departs, leaving the body, attains the Supreme Goal.

Questions: what is the meaning and significance of om tat sat?
Answers: I am easily attainable by that ever-steadfast yogi who constantly and daily remembers me for a long time, not thinking of anything else with a single-minded or one-pointed focus, O Partha.

Questions: what is the meaning and significance of om tat sat?
Answers: Having attained Me, these great souls do not take birth again here—a place of pain and impermanence—but have reached the highest perfection of liberation.

Questions: What is the threefold designation of Brahman?
Answers: All the worlds, including the world of Brahma, are subject to return again, O Arjuna; but he who reaches Me, O son of Kunti, has no rebirth.

Questions: What is the threefold designation of Brahman?
Answers: Those who know the day of Brahma, which lasts a thousand Yugas, and the night, which also lasts a thousand Yugas, know day and night.

Questions: What is the threefold designation of Brahman?
Answers: From the Unmanifested, all the manifested worlds proceed upon the arrival of the 'day'; upon the arrival of the 'night', they dissolve indeed into that which is known as the Unmanifested.

Questions: What is the threefold designation of Brahman?
Answers: This same multitude of beings, being born again and again, helplessly dissolves, O Arjuna, into the Unmanifested at the coming of the night and comes forth at the coming of the day.

Questions: What is the significance of Om?
Answers: But verily, there exists higher than this Unmanifested, another Unmanifested Eternal, which is not destroyed even when all beings are destroyed.

Questions: What is the significance of Om?
Answers: What is known as the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That is said to be the highest goal. Those who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My supreme abode (place or state).

Questions: What is the significance of Om?
Answers: That highest Purusha, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion to Him alone, within Whom all beings dwell and by Whom all this is pervaded.

Questions: What is the significance of Om?
Answers: Now I will tell you, O chief of the Bharatas, the times of departure at which the Yogis will return or not return.

Questions: What is the meaning of Om?
Answers: Fire, light, daytime, the bright fortnight, the six months of the northern path of the sun (the northern solstice) departing, then men who know Brahman go to Brahman.

Questions: What is the meaning of Om?
Answers: Attaining the lunar light through smoke, night time, the dark fortnight, and the six months of the southern path of the sun (the southern solstice), the yogi returns.

Questions: What is the meaning of Om?
Answers: The bright and dark paths of the world are thought to be eternal; one leads to no return, and the other leads to return.

Questions: What is the meaning of Om?
Answers: Knowing these paths, O Arjuna, no yogi is deluded; therefore, at all times, be steadfast in yoga.

Questions: What is the significance of Aum?
Answers: Whatever fruit of merit is declared (in the scriptures) to accrue from (the study of) the Vedas, (the performance of) sacrifices, (the practice of) austerities, and gifts, beyond all this goes the Yogi, having known this; and he attains to the Supreme, Primeval (first or ancient) Abode.

Questions: What is the significance of Aum?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "I shall now declare to thee, who does not cavil, the greatest secret—the knowledge combined with experience (Self-realisation). Having known this, thou shalt be free from evil."

Questions: What is the significance of Aum?
Answers: This is the royal science, the royal secret, the supreme purifier, realizable by direct intuitive knowledge, according to righteousness, very easy to perform and imperishable.

Questions: What is the significance of Aum?
Answers: Those who have no faith in this Dharma, O Parantapa, return to the path of this world without attaining Me.

Questions: What is the meaning of AUM?
Answers: All of this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest aspect; all beings exist within Me, but I do not dwell within them.

Questions: What is the meaning of AUM?
Answers: Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold, My divine Yoga, which supports all beings, but does not dwell in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.

Questions: What is the meaning of AUM?
Answers: As the mighty wind, moving everywhere, always rests in the ether, so too, know that all beings rest in Me.

Questions: What is the meaning of AUM?
Answers: All beings, O Arjuna, go into My Nature at the end of a Kalpa; I send them forth again at the beginning of the next Kalpa.

Questions: How should we perform sacrifices?
Answers: Animating My Nature, I again and again send forth all this multitude of beings, helpless under the force of Nature.

Questions: How should we perform sacrifices?
Answers: These acts do not bind Me, O Arjuna, sitting as one indifferent, unattached to those acts.

Questions: How should we perform sacrifices?
Answers: Under Me, as supervisor, Nature produces the moving and the unmoving; therefore, O Arjuna, the world revolves.

Questions: How should we perform sacrifices?
Answers: Fools disregard Me, clad in human form, not knowing My higher Being as the great Lord of all beings.

Questions: What is the best way of performing sacrifices?
Answers: They are possessed of the deceitful nature of demons and undivine beings, filled with vain hopes, vain actions, and vain knowledge that is senseless.

Questions: What is the best way of performing sacrifices?
Answers: But the great souls, O Arjuna, partaking of My divine nature, worship Me with a single-minded devotion, knowing Me as the imperishable source of all beings.

Questions: What is the best way of performing sacrifices?
Answers: Always glorifying Me, striving, firm in their vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me with steadfast devotion.

Questions: What is the best way of performing sacrifices?
Answers: Others also, sacrificing with the wisdom-sacrifice, worship Me, the All-Faced, as one, distinct, and manifold.

Questions: How should we perform rituals?
Answers: I am Kratu; I am Yajna; I am the offering to the manes; I am the medicinal herbs and all plants; I am the Mantra; I am also the ghee or melted butter; I am the fire; I am the oblation.

Questions: How should we perform rituals?
Answers: I am the father of this world, the mother, the dispenser of the fruits of actions, and the grandfather; the one thing to be known, the purifier, the sacred monosyllable (Om), and also the Rik, Sama, and Yajur Vedas.

Questions: How should we perform rituals?
Answers: I am the father of this world, the mother, the dispenser of the fruits of actions, and the grandfather; the one thing to be known, the purifier, the sacred monosyllable (Om), and also the Rik, Sama, and Yajur Vedas.

Questions: How should we perform rituals?
Answers: I am the father of this world, the mother, the dispenser of the fruits of actions, and the grandfather; the one thing to be known, the purifier, the sacred monosyllable (Om), and also the Rik, Sama, and Yajur Vedas.

Questions: What is the best way of performing rituals?
Answers: I am the goal, the supporter, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the shelter, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house, and the imperishable seed.

Questions: What is the best way of performing rituals?
Answers: I am the goal, the supporter, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the shelter, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house, and the imperishable seed.

Questions: What is the best way of performing rituals?
Answers: As the sun, I give heat; I withhold and send forth the rain; I am immortality and also death, existence and non-existence, O Arjuna.

Questions: What is the best way of performing rituals?
Answers: The knowers of the three Vedas, the drinkers of Soma, purified of all sins, worshipping Me through sacrifices, pray for the way to heaven; they reach the holy world of the Lord of the gods and enjoy the divine pleasures of the gods in heaven.

Questions: What does the word tat mean?
Answers: They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the three (Vedas) and desiring objects of desires, they attain to the state of coming and going.

Questions: What does the word tat mean?
Answers: For those men who worship Me alone, thinking of no one else, for those ever-united, I secure what they have not already possessed and preserve what they already possess.

Questions: What does the word tat mean?
Answers: Even those devotees who, endowed with faith, worship other gods, worship Me alone, O Arjuna, but by the wrong method.

Questions: What does the word tat mean?
Answers: For I alone am the enjoyer and Lord of all sacrifices; but they do not know Me in reality, and thus they return to this mortal world.

Questions: What is the meaning of Sat?
Answers: The worshippers of the gods go to them; the ancestor-worshippers go to the manes; the worshippers of the deities who preside over the elements go to them; but My devotees come to Me.

Questions: What is the meaning of Sat?
Answers: Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit, or a little water, that, so offered devotedly by the pure-minded, I accept.

Questions: What is the meaning of Sat?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: What is the meaning of Sat?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: What is the significance of sat?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: What is the significance of sat?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: What is the significance of sat?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: What is the significance of sat?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: what is asat or untruth?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: what is asat or untruth?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: what is asat or untruth?
Answers: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.

Questions: what is asat or untruth?
Answers: Thus, you shall be freed from the bonds of actions yielding good and evil fruits; with the mind steadfast in the Yoga of renunciation, and liberated, you shall come to Me.

Questions: Was Arjuna curious about renunciation?
Answers: I am the same to all beings; there is none hateful or dear to Me; but those who worship Me with devotion are in Me, and I am also in them.

Questions: Was Arjuna curious about renunciation?
Answers: Even if the most sinful worships Me, with devotion to no one else, he should indeed be regarded as righteous, for he has rightly resolved.

Questions: Was Arjuna curious about renunciation?
Answers: Soon he becomes righteous and attains eternal peace; O Arjuna, proclaim thou for certain that My devotee never perishes.

Questions: Was Arjuna curious about renunciation?
Answers: For, taking refuge in Me, they who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth—women, Vaisyas, and Sudras—attain the Supreme Goal.

Questions: What is sannyasa?
Answers: For, taking refuge in Me, they who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth—women, Vaisyas, and Sudras—attain the Supreme Goal.

Questions: What is sannyasa?
Answers: For, taking refuge in Me, they who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth—women, Vaisyas, and Sudras—attain the Supreme Goal.

Questions: What is sannyasa?
Answers: For, taking refuge in Me, they who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth—women, Vaisyas, and Sudras—attain the Supreme Goal.

Questions: What is sannyasa?
Answers: How much more easily, then, do Brahmins and devoted royal saints attain the goal? Having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me.

Questions: What is renunciation?
Answers: Fix your mind on Me; be devoted to Me; sacrifice to Me; bow down to Me; having thus united your whole self to Me, taking Me as the supreme goal, you will come to Me.

Questions: What is renunciation?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, Again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen to my supreme word which I will declare to you, who are beloved, for your welfare.

Questions: What is renunciation?
Answers: Neither the hosts of the gods nor the great sages know My origin; for I am the source of all the gods and the great sages in every way.

Questions: What is renunciation?
Answers: He who knows Me as unborn and beginningless, as the great Lord of the worlds, he among mortals is undeluded and is liberated from all sins.

Questions: Should all actions be abandoned as evil?
Answers: Intellect, wisdom, non-delusion, forgiveness, truth, self-restraint, calmness, happiness, pain, existence or birth, non-existence or death, fear, and also fearlessness.

Questions: Should all actions be abandoned as evil?
Answers: Non-injury, equanimity, contentment, austerity, beneficence, fame, and ill-fame—these different qualities of beings arise from Me alone.

Questions: Should all actions be abandoned as evil?
Answers: The seven great sages, the ancient four, and the Manus, possessing powers like Mine (due to their minds being fixed on Me), were born from My mind; from them, these creatures have been born in this world.

Questions: Should all actions be abandoned as evil?
Answers: He who truly knows these manifold manifestations of My Being and this Yoga-power of Mine, becomes established in unshakable Yoga; there is no doubt about it.

Questions: How many types of tyaga are there?
Answers: I am the source of all; from me everything evolves; Understanding this, the wise, endowed with meditation, worship me.

Questions: How many types of tyaga are there?
Answers: With their minds and lives wholly absorbed in Me, they enlighten each other and ever speak of Me, being satisfied and delighted.

Questions: How many types of tyaga are there?
Answers: To those who are ever steadfast, worshipping me with love, I give the yoga of discrimination, by which they come to me.

Questions: How many types of tyaga are there?
Answers: Out of mere compassion for them, I, dwelling within their selves, destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the luminous lamp of knowledge.

Questions: Should we abandon all sacrifices and austerities?
Answers: Arjuna said, "You are the Supreme Brahman, the supreme abode, the supreme purifier, eternal, divine Person, the primeval God, unborn, and omnipresent."

Questions: Should we abandon all sacrifices and austerities?
Answers: All the sages have thus declared Thee, as also the divine sage Narada; so also Asita, Devala, and Vyasa; and now Thou Thyself dost say so to me.

Questions: Should we abandon all sacrifices and austerities?
Answers: I believe all that You have said to me to be true, O Krishna; indeed, O blessed Lord! Neither the gods nor the demons know Your manifestation (origin).

Questions: Should we abandon all sacrifices and austerities?
Answers: Verily, Thou Thyself knowest Thyself by Thyself, O Supreme Person, O source and Lord of all beings, O God of gods, O ruler of the world!

Questions: What are the means of purification for the wise?
Answers: You should indeed tell, without reserve, of your divine glories by which you exist, pervading all these worlds. (No one else can do so.)

Questions: What are the means of purification for the wise?
Answers: How shall I, ever meditating, know you, O Yogin? In what aspects or things, O blessed Lord, should I think of you?

Questions: What are the means of purification for the wise?
Answers: Tell me again in detail, O Krishna, of your yogic power and glory; for I am not satiated with what I have heard of your life-giving and nectar-like speech.

Questions: What are the means of purification for the wise?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Very well! Now I will declare to you My divine glories in their prominence, O Arjuna; there is no end to their detailed description."

Questions: Is there any need of performing the rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: I am the Self, O Gudakesa, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning, the middle, and the end of all beings.

Questions: Is there any need of performing the rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among the twelve Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminaries, the radiant sun; among the seven or forty-nine Maruts, I am Marichi; among stars, I am the moon.

Questions: Is there any need of performing the rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among the Vedas, I am the Sama-Veda; among the gods, I am Vasava; among the senses, I am the mind; and among living beings, I am intelligence.

Questions: Is there any need of performing the rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: And among the Rudras, I am Sankara; among the Yakshas and Rakshasas, the Lord of Wealth (Kubera); among the Vasus, I am Pavaka (Fire); and among the seven mountains, I am Meru.

Questions: Is it good to renounce rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: And, among the household priests of kings, O Arjuna, know Me to be the chief, Brihaspati; among the army generals, I am Skanda; among lakes, I am the ocean.

Questions: Is it good to renounce rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among the great sages, I am Bhrigu; among words, I am the one syllable (Om); among sacrifices, I am the sacrifice of silent repetition; among the immovable things, I am the Himalayas.

Questions: Is it good to renounce rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among all the trees, I am the Peepul; among the divine sages, I am Narada; among the Gandharvas, I am Chitraratha; among the perfected, I am the sage Kapila.

Questions: Is it good to renounce rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Know Me as Ucchaisravas, born of nectar, among horses; Airavata among lordly elephants; and the king among men.

Questions: What happens to those who abandon the rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt; among cows, I am the wish-fulfilling cow called Kamadhenu; I am the progenitor, the god of love; among serpents, I am Vasuki.

Questions: What happens to those who abandon the rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: I am Ananta among the Nagas; I am Varuna among water-deities; Aryaman among the Manes; I am Yama among the governors.

Questions: What happens to those who abandon the rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: And I am Prahlada among the demons, I am Time among reckoners, I am the lion among beasts, and Vainateya (Garuda) among birds.

Questions: What happens to those who abandon the rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among the purifiers, I am the wind; among the warriors, I am Rama; among the fishes, I am the shark; among the streams, I am the Ganga.

Questions: What is a sattvic way of performing rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among creations I am the beginning, the middle, and the end, O Arjuna; among the sciences, I am the science of the Self; and I am the logic among controversialists.

Questions: What is a sattvic way of performing rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among the letters of the alphabet, I am the letter 'A' and the dual among compounds. I am verily the inexhaustible and everlasting time; I am the dispenser of the fruits of actions, having faces in all directions.

Questions: What is a sattvic way of performing rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: And I am the all-devouring Death, and the source of prosperity for those who are to be prosperous; among the feminine qualities, I am fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness, and forgiveness.

Questions: What is a sattvic way of performing rituals and sacrifices?
Answers: Among the hymns, I am the Brihatsaman; among meters, I am Gayatri; among months, I am Margasirsha; among seasons, I am the flowery season.

Questions: What are the characteristics of a sattvic person?
Answers: I am the gambling of the deceitful; I am the splendor of the splendid; I am victory; I am the resolve of the resolute; I am the goodness of the good.

Questions: What are the characteristics of a sattvic person?
Answers: Among the Vrishnis, I am Vaasudeva; among the Pandavas, I am Arjuna; among the sages, I am Vyasa; among the poets, I am Usanas, the poet.

Questions: What are the characteristics of a sattvic person?
Answers: Of those who punish, I am the scepter; among those who seek victory, I am statesmanship; and among secrets, I am silence; I am knowledge among knowers.

Questions: What are the characteristics of a sattvic person?
Answers: And whatever is the seed of all beings, that too am I, O Arjuna; there is no being, be it moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me.

Questions: What are the characteristics of a pure person?
Answers: There is no end to My divine glories, O Arjuna, but this is a brief statement by Me of the particulars of My divine glory.

Questions: What are the characteristics of a pure person?
Answers: Whatever being there is glorious, prosperous, or powerful, know that to be a manifestation of a part of My splendor.

Questions: What are the characteristics of a pure person?
Answers: But, of what avail is the knowledge of all these details to you, O Arjuna? I exist, supporting this whole world with one part of Myself.

Questions: What are the characteristics of a pure person?
Answers: Arjuna said, By this explanation of the highest secret concerning the Self which Thou hast spoken, for the sake of blessing me, my delusion has been dispelled.

Questions: Is it possible to completely abandon actions?
Answers: The origin and destruction of beings have been heard in detail from You, O lotus-eyed Lord, and also Your inexhaustible greatness.

Questions: Is it possible to completely abandon actions?
Answers: Now, O Supreme Lord, as Thou hast thus described Thyself, O Supreme Person, I wish to behold Thy divine form.

Questions: Is it possible to completely abandon actions?
Answers: If Thou, O Lord, thinkest it possible for me to see it, do Thou, then, O Lord of the Yogis, show me Thy imperishable Self.

Questions: Is it possible to completely abandon actions?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "Behold, O Arjuna, forms of Mine, by the hundreds and thousands, of different sorts, divine, and of various colors and shapes."

Questions: Is it possible to completely give up actions?
Answers: Behold the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Asvins, and the Maruts; behold many wonders never before seen, O Arjuna.

Questions: Is it possible to completely give up actions?
Answers: Now, behold, O Arjuna, in this My body, the entire universe centered in one, including the moving and the unmoving, and whatever else you desire to see.

Questions: Is it possible to completely give up actions?
Answers: But you are not able to behold Me with these your own eyes; I give you the divine eye; behold My lordly Yoga.

Questions: Is it possible to completely give up actions?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken, O king, the great Lord of Yoga, Hari (Krishna), showed Arjuna His supreme form as the Lord.

Questions: What are the kinds of fruits of actions?
Answers: With numerous mouths and eyes, with numerous wondrous sights, with numerous divine adornments, with numerous divine weapons uplifted, such a form He showed.

Questions: What are the kinds of fruits of actions?
Answers: Wearing divine garlands and apparel, anointed with divine unguents, the all-wonderful, resplendent Being is endless with faces on all sides.

Questions: What are the kinds of fruits of actions?
Answers: If the splendour of a thousand suns were to blaze out simultaneously in the sky, that would be the splendour of that mighty being.

Questions: What are the kinds of fruits of actions?
Answers: There, in the body of the God of gods, Arjuna then saw the entire universe resting in one, with its myriad of divisions.

Questions: What are the causes that lead to accomplishment of all actions?
Answers: Then, Arjuna, filled with wonder and his hair standing on end, bowed his head to the God and spoke with palms joined.

Questions: What are the causes that lead to accomplishment of all actions?
Answers: Arjuna said, "O God, I see all the gods in Your body, as well as hosts of various classes of beings, Brahma the Lord seated on the lotus, all the sages, and the celestial serpents."

Questions: What are the causes that lead to accomplishment of all actions?
Answers: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.

Questions: What are the causes that lead to accomplishment of all actions?
Answers: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.

Questions: What are the causes that determine the fruits of our actions?
Answers: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.

Questions: What are the causes that determine the fruits of our actions?
Answers: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.

Questions: What are the causes that determine the fruits of our actions?
Answers: I see You with the diadem, club, and discus, a mass of radiance shining everywhere, very hard to look at, blazing all around like a burning fire and the sun, and immeasurable.

Questions: What are the causes that determine the fruits of our actions?
Answers: You are the Imperishable, the Supreme Being, worthy of being known. You are the great treasure-house of this universe; You are the imperishable protector of the eternal Dharma; You are the Primal Person, I believe.

Questions: Do all actions have similar causes at a fundamental level?
Answers: I see You without beginning, middle, or end, infinite in power, with endless arms, the sun and moon as Your eyes, the burning fire Your mouth, heating the entire universe with Your radiance.

Questions: Do all actions have similar causes at a fundamental level?
Answers: This space between the earth and the heavens, and all the quarters, is filled by You alone; having seen this, Your wonderful and terrible form, the three worlds are trembling with fear, O great-souled Being.

Questions: Do all actions have similar causes at a fundamental level?
Answers: Verily, these hosts of gods enter into Thee; some extol Thee with joined palms in fear, saying, 'May it be well!' Bands of great sages and perfected ones praise Thee with complete hymns.

Questions: Do all actions have similar causes at a fundamental level?
Answers: The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, the two Asvins, Maruts, the Manus, and the hosts of celestial singers, Yakshas, demons, and the perfected ones, all look upon Thee with great amazement.

Questions: Can everyone perceive the self?
Answers: Having seen Your immeasurable form with many mouths and eyes, O mighty-armed one, with many arms, thighs, and feet, with many stomachs and fearsome with many teeth, the worlds are terrified, and so am I.

Questions: Can everyone perceive the self?
Answers: On seeing Thee, touching the sky, shining in many colors, with mouths wide open, with large fiery eyes, I am terrified at heart and find neither courage nor peace, O Vishnu.

Questions: Can everyone perceive the self?
Answers: Having seen Thy mouths fearful with teeth blazing like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I know not the four quarters, nor do I find peace. Have mercy, O Lord of the gods, O abode of the universe.

Questions: Can everyone perceive the self?
Answers: All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the hosts of kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona, and Karna, as well as the chief among our warriors.

Questions: What kind of attitude should we have while performing action?
Answers: Some hurry into Your mouths with their terrible teeth, fearful to behold. Some are found stuck in the gaps between the teeth, their heads crushed to powder.

Questions: What kind of attitude should we have while performing action?
Answers: Verily, just as many torrents of rivers flow towards the ocean, so too these heroes in the world of men enter Thy flaming mouths.

Questions: What kind of attitude should we have while performing action?
Answers: As moths hurriedly rush into a blazing fire, leading to their own destruction, so too these creatures hurry into Your mouths, leading to their own destruction.

Questions: What kind of attitude should we have while performing action?
Answers: Thou lickest up, devouring all the worlds on every side with Thy flaming mouths. Thy fierce rays, filling the whole world with radiance, burn, O Vishnu!

Questions: Who is the doer of all actions?
Answers: Tell me, who you are, so fierce of form. I offer my salutations to you, O God Supreme; have mercy on me. I desire to know you, the original Being. I do not indeed know your workings.

Questions: Who is the doer of all actions?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "I am the full-grown, world-destroying Time, now engaged in destroying the worlds. Even without you, none of the warriors arrayed in the hostile armies will live."

Questions: Who is the doer of all actions?
Answers: Therefore, stand up and obtain fame. Conquer the enemies and enjoy the unparalleled kingdom. Verily, by Me they have already been slain; be thou a mere instrument, O Arjuna.

Questions: Who is the doer of all actions?
Answers: Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other brave warriors have already been slain by Me; do not be distressed with fear; fight and you shall conquer your enemies in battle.

Questions: What incites a person to act?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having heard that speech of Lord Krishna, Arjuna, with joined palms, trembling, prostrated himself, again addressing Krishna in a choked voice, bowing down, overwhelmed with fear.

Questions: What incites a person to act?
Answers: Arjuna said, "It is fitting, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Your praise; demons fly in fear in all directions and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to You."

Questions: What incites a person to act?
Answers: And why should they not, O great Soul, bow to Thee Who art greater than all else, the primal cause even of the Creator (Brahma), O Infinite Being, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe; Thou art the imperishable, the Being, the non-being, and That which is supreme—that which is beyond the Being and the non-being.

Questions: What incites a person to act?
Answers: You are the primal God, the ancient Purusha, the supreme refuge of this universe, the knower, the knowable, and the supreme Abode. Through You, the universe is pervaded, O Being of infinite forms.

Questions: What incites a person to perform action?
Answers: You are Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the moon, the Creator, and the great-grandfather. I offer my salutations to You a thousand times, and again I offer my salutations to You.

Questions: What incites a person to perform action?
Answers: Salutations to You in front and behind! Salutations to You on every side! O All! You, infinite in power and prowess, pervade all; therefore You are all.

Questions: What incites a person to perform action?
Answers: Whatever I have presumptuously said from carelessness or love, addressing You as O Krishna! O Yadava! O Friend! regarding You merely as a friend, unknowing of Your greatness.

Questions: What incites a person to perform action?
Answers: In whatever way I may have insulted You for the sake of fun, while at play, reposing, sitting, or at meals, when alone (with You), O Krishna, or in company, that I implore You, immeasurable one, to forgive.

Questions: How many kinds of knowledge are there?
Answers: Thou art the Father of this world, both moving and unmoving. Thou art to be adored by this world; Thou, the greatest Guru; for none exists who is equal to Thee; how then could there be another superior to Thee in the three worlds, O Being of unrivaled power?

Questions: How many kinds of knowledge are there?
Answers: Therefore, bowing down and prostrating my body, I crave Thy forgiveness, O adorable Lord. As a father forgives his son, a friend his dear friend, a lover his beloved, even so may Thou forgive me, O God.

Questions: How many kinds of knowledge are there?
Answers: I am delighted, having seen something never seen before; yet my mind is distressed with fear. Show me that form only, O God; have mercy, O God of gods, O Abode of the universe.

Questions: How many kinds of knowledge are there?
Answers: I desire to see You as before, crowned, bearing a mace, with the discus in hand, in Your former form only, having four arms, O thousand-armed, Cosmic Being.

Questions: How many kinds of actions are there?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, this Cosmic Form has graciously been shown to you by Me through My own Yogic power. It is full of splendour, primeval, and infinite; this Cosmic Form of Mine has never been seen before by anyone other than you."

Questions: How many kinds of actions are there?
Answers: Neither by the study of the Vedas, nor by gifts, nor by sacrifices, nor by severe austerities, can I be seen in this form in the world of men by any other than yourself, O great hero of the Kurus (Arjuna).

Questions: How many kinds of actions are there?
Answers: Neither by the study of the Vedas, nor by gifts, nor by sacrifices, nor by severe austerities, can I be seen in this form in the world of men by any other than yourself, O great hero of the Kurus (Arjuna).

Questions: How many kinds of actions are there?
Answers: Do not be afraid, nor be bewildered on seeing such a terrible form of Mine; with your fear dispelled and with a gladdened heart, now behold again this former form of Mine.

Questions: Which knowledge is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form. The great Soul, assuming His gentle form, then consoled Arjuna, who was terrified.

Questions: Which knowledge is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and have been restored to my own nature."

Questions: Which knowledge is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "It is very hard indeed to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen; even the gods are ever longing to behold it."

Questions: Which knowledge is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "It is very hard indeed to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen; even the gods are ever longing to behold it."

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Neither by the Vedas, nor by austerity, nor by gift, nor by sacrifice can I be seen in this form as thou hast seen Me so easily.

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: But by single-minded devotion, I can be known, seen, and entered into in reality, O Arjuna.

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: He who does all actions for Me, who regards Me as the Supreme, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who bears no enmity towards any creature, he comes to Me, O Arjuna.

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Arjuna said, "Which of them are better versed in Yoga—those who steadfastly worship You, or those who worship the imperishable and the unmanifested?"

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "In My opinion, those who fix their minds on Me, worship Me ever steadfastly, and are endowed with supreme faith, are the best in Yoga."

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Those who worship the imperishable, the indefinable, the unmanifest, the omnipresent, the unthinkable, the immovable, and the eternal.

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Having restrained all the senses, being even-minded everywhere, and intent on the welfare of all beings, they verily come unto Me.

Questions: What kind of knowledge is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Greater is their trouble whose minds are set on the unmanifested, for the goal of the unmanifested is very hard for the embodied to reach.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: But to those who worship Me, renouncing all actions in Me, regarding Me as the supreme goal, meditating on Me with single-minded yoga.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: To those whose minds are set on Me, O Arjuna, verily I soon become the savior out of the ocean of Samsara.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Fix your mind on Me, and your intellect in Me. Then you will certainly live in Me alone hereafter.

Questions: Which action is considered to be sattvic?
Answers: Fix your mind on Me, and your intellect in Me. Then you will certainly live in Me alone hereafter.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: Fix your mind on Me, and your intellect in Me. Then you will certainly live in Me alone hereafter.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: If you are unable to fix your mind steadily on Me, then seek to reach Me through the yoga of constant practice, O Arjuna.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: If you are unable to practice even this Abhyasa Yoga, be intent on doing actions for My sake; even by doing actions for My sake, you will attain perfection.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?
Answers: If you are unable to do even this, then, resort to union with Me and renounce the fruits of all actions with self-control.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Better indeed is knowledge than practice; better than knowledge is meditation; better than meditation is the renunciation of the fruits of actions: peace immediately follows renunciation.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: He who hates no creature, is friendly and compassionate to all, is free from attachment and egoism, is balanced in pleasure and pain, and is forgiving.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessing firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devotee, is dear to Me.

Questions: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?
Answers: Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessing firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devotee, is dear to Me.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: He whom the world does not agitate, and who cannot be agitated by the world, and who is freed from joy, anger, fear, and anxiety—he is dear to Me.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings and commencements, he who is devoted to Me is dear to Me.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings and commencements, he who is devoted to Me is dear to Me.

Questions: What kind of person is considered sattvic?
Answers: He who neither rejoices nor hates, nor grieves nor desires, renouncing both good and evil, and who is full of devotion, is dear to Me.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: He who is the same to foe and friend, and also in honor and dishonor, who is the same in cold and heat, in pleasure and pain, and who is free from attachment.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: He to whom censure and praise are equal, who is silent, content with anything, homeless, of a steady mind, and full of devotion; that man is dear to me.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: They who follow this immortal Dharma, endowed with faith and regarding Me as their supreme goal, are exceedingly dear to Me.

Questions: What kind of person is considered rajasic?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, this body is called the field; he who knows it is called the knower of the field by those who know them."

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: Do thou also know Me as the knower of the field in all fields, O Arjuna. Knowledge of both the field and the knower of the field is considered by Me to be the knowledge.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: Hear from Me in brief what the field is, of what nature it is, what its modifications are, whence it is, who He is, and what His powers are.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: Sages have sung in many ways, with various distinctive chants and also with suggestive words indicative of the Absolute, full of reasoning and decisive.

Questions: What kind of person is considered tamasic?
Answers: The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses, and one mind, and the five objects of the senses.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (body), intelligence, and fortitude—the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service to the teacher, purity, steadfastness, and self-control.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perceiving the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness, and pain.

Questions: What are the different kinds of buddhi?
Answers: Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home, and the rest, and constant even-mindedness in the face of the attainment of both desirable and undesirable.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?
Answers: Unswerving devotion to Me through the Yoga of non-separation, resorting to solitary places, and a distaste for the company of people.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?
Answers: Constancy in Self-knowledge, the perception of the end of true knowledge—this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?
Answers: I will declare that which is to be known, knowing which one attains immortality; the beginningless Supreme Brahman, which is neither being nor non-being.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?
Answers: With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads, and mouths everywhere, with ears everywhere, He exists in the worlds, enveloping all.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: Shining by the functions of all the senses, yet without being attached to them; unattached, yet supporting all; devoid of qualities, yet the experiencer of them.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: It is within and without all beings, both the unmoving and the moving; It is subtle and unknowable, and It is near and far away.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: Undivided yet, It exists as if divided in beings; It is to be known as the supporter of beings; It devours and It generates.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?
Answers: That Light of all lights is said to be beyond darkness: knowledge, the knowable, and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: Thus, the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable, have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My being.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: Thus, the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable, have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My being.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: Know that Nature (matter) and the Spirit are both beginningless, and know also that all modifications and qualities are born from Nature.

Questions: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?
Answers: In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the one responsible.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered sattvic?
Answers: The soul seated in Nature experiences the qualities born of Nature; attachment to the qualities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered sattvic?
Answers: The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the observer, the permitter, the sustainer, the enjoyer, the great Lord, and the Supreme Self.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered sattvic?
Answers: He who thus knows the Spirit and Matter together with their qualities, in whatever condition he may be, he is not reborn.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered sattvic?
Answers: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered rajasic?
Answers: Others, too, who do not know thus, worship, having heard of It from others; they, too, cross beyond death, regarding what they have heard as the supreme refuge.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered rajasic?
Answers: Wherever a being is born, whether unmoving or moving, know thou, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), that it is from the union of the field and its knower.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered rajasic?
Answers: He who sees the Supreme Lord existing truly in all beings, the imperishable within the perishable, sees indeed.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered rajasic?
Answers: For he who truly sees the same Lord dwelling everywhere does not destroy the Self by the self; rather, he attains the highest goal.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered tamasic?
Answers: He sees, who sees that all actions are performed solely by Nature and that the Self is without action.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered tamasic?
Answers: When a person sees all beings as resting in the One and emanating from the One alone, they then become Brahman.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered tamasic?
Answers: Being without beginning, devoid of any qualities, the Supreme Self, imperishable, though dwelling in the body, O Arjuna, neither acts nor is tainted.

Questions: What kind of firmness is considered tamasic?
Answers: As the all-pervading ether is not tainted, due to its subtlety, so the Self seated everywhere in the body is not tainted either.

Questions: How many kinds of pleasures are there?
Answers: Just as the one sun illuminates the entire world, so too does the Lord of the field (Supreme Self) illuminate the entire field, O Arjuna.

Questions: How many kinds of pleasures are there?
Answers: They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower, as well as the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.

Questions: How many kinds of pleasures are there?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "I will again declare to thee that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, having known which all the sages have gone to supreme perfection after this life."

Questions: How many kinds of pleasures are there?
Answers: Those who, having taken refuge in this knowledge, have attained unity with Me, are neither born at the time of creation nor disturbed at the time of dissolution.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered sattvic?
Answers: My womb is the great Brahma; in it I place the germ; thence, O Arjuna, is the birth of all beings.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered sattvic?
Answers: Whatever forms are produced, O Arjuna, in any womb whatsoever, the great Brahma is their womb, and I am the seed-giving father.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered sattvic?
Answers: These qualities, O Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body of the embodied, the indestructible: purity, passion, and inertia.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered sattvic?
Answers: Of these, sattva, which is luminous and healthy due to its stainlessness, binds one by attachment to happiness and knowledge, O sinless one.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered rajasic?
Answers: Know, O Arjuna, that Rajas is of the nature of passion, the source of thirst and attachment; it binds fast the embodied one by attachment to action.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered rajasic?
Answers: But know thou Tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds fast, O Arjuna, through heedlessness, indolence, and sleep.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered rajasic?
Answers: Sattva attaches to happiness, Rajas to action, O Arjuna, while Tamas, verily shrouding knowledge, attaches to heedlessness.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered rajasic?
Answers: Now, O Arjuna, Sattva prevails, having overpowered Rajas and Tamas; then Rajas, having overpowered Sattva and Tamas; and then Tamas, having overpowered Sattva and Rajas.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered tamasic?
Answers: When the wisdom-light shines through every gate of this body, then it may be known that Sattva is predominant.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered tamasic?
Answers: Greed, activity, the undertaking of actions, restlessness, and longing—these arise when Rajas is predominant, O Arjuna.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered tamasic?
Answers: Darkness, inertia, carelessness, and delusion—these arise when Tamas is predominant, O Arjuna.

Questions: What kind of pleasure is considered tamasic?
Answers: If the embodied one meets death when Sattva is predominant, then they attain the spotless worlds of the knowers of the Highest.

Questions: Is there anyone in this universe free from the three gunas?
Answers: Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the thoughtless.

Questions: Is there anyone in this universe free from the three gunas?
Answers: Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the thoughtless.

Questions: Is there anyone in this universe free from the three gunas?
Answers: They say that the fruit of good action is Sattvic and pure; indeed, the fruit of Rajas is pain, and the fruit of Tamas is ignorance.

Questions: Is there anyone in this universe free from the three gunas?
Answers: They say that the fruit of good action is Sattvic and pure; indeed, the fruit of Rajas is pain, and the fruit of Tamas is ignorance.

Questions: What is the varna system in Hinduism?
Answers: They say that the fruit of good action is Sattvic and pure; indeed, the fruit of Rajas is pain, and the fruit of Tamas is ignorance.

Questions: What is the varna system in Hinduism?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What is the varna system in Hinduism?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What is the varna system in Hinduism?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What is the caste system in Hinduism?
Answers: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.

Questions: What is the caste system in Hinduism?
Answers: Those seated in Sattva ascend; those of Rajasic nature dwell in the middle; and those of Tamasic nature, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, descend.

Questions: What is the caste system in Hinduism?
Answers: Those seated in Sattva ascend; those of Rajasic nature dwell in the middle; and those of Tamasic nature, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, descend.

Questions: What is the caste system in Hinduism?
Answers: Those seated in Sattva ascend; those of Rajasic nature dwell in the middle; and those of Tamasic nature, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, descend.

Questions: Is caste decided by birth or by personal preference?
Answers: When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows that which is higher than them, he attains to My Being.

Questions: Is caste decided by birth or by personal preference?
Answers: The embodied one, having crossed beyond these three Gunas from which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay, and pain, and attains immortality.

Questions: Is caste decided by birth or by personal preference?
Answers: Arjuna said, "What are the marks of one who has transcended the three qualities, O Lord? What is their conduct, and how do they go beyond these three qualities?"

Questions: Is caste decided by birth or by personal preference?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said, "When light, activity, and delusion are present, he does not hate them, nor does he long for them when they are absent.

Questions: Is varna decided by birth or by personal preference?
Answers: He who, seated like one unconcerned, is not moved by the dualities, and who, knowing that the dualities are active, is self-centered and does not move.

Questions: Is varna decided by birth or by personal preference?
Answers: Who is the same in pleasure and pain, who dwells in the Self, to whom a clod of earth, a stone, and gold are all alike, who is the same to the dear and the unfriendly, who is firm, and to whom censure and praise are one and the same.

Questions: Is varna decided by birth or by personal preference?
Answers: Who is the same in honor and dishonor, the same to friend and foe, abandoning all undertakings, he is said to have transcended the dualities.

Questions: Is varna decided by birth or by personal preference?
Answers: And he who serves Me with unwavering devotion, he, crossing beyond the dualities, is fit for becoming Brahman.

Questions: Who is a Brahmin?
Answers: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.

Questions: Who is a Brahmin?
Answers: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.

Answers: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.

Answers: The Blessed Lord said: They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree, with its roots above and branches below, whose leaves are the meters or hymns; he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.

Questions: What are the qualities of a Brahmin?
Answers: The Blessed Lord said: They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree, with its roots above and branches below, whose leaves are the meters or hymns; he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.

Questions: What are the qualities of a Brahmin?
Answers: Its branches spread below and above, nourished by the Gunas; its buds are sense-objects, and its roots stretch forth below in the world of men, originating action.

Questions: What are the qualities of a Brahmin?
Answers: Its form is not perceived here as such, nor its end, origin, foundation, or resting place; having cut asunder this firmly rooted peepul tree with the strong axe of non-attachment.

Questions: What are the qualities of a Brahmin?
